verses.verse: I am come <WH935> into my garden <WH1588>, my sister <WH269>, my bride <WH3618>: I have gathered <WH717> my myrrh <WH4753> with my spice <WH1313>; I have eaten <WH398> my honeycomb <WH3293> with my honey <WH1706>; I have drunk <WH8354> my wine <WH3196> with my milk <WH2461>. Eat <WH398>, O friends <WH7453>; Drink <WH8354>, yea <WH7937>, drink abundantly, O beloved <WH1730>.

I was asleep <WH3463>, but my heart <WH3820> waked <WH5782>: It is the voice <WH6963> of my beloved <WH1730> that knocketh <WH1849>, saying <WH6605>, Open to me <WH269>, my sister, my love <WH7474>, my dove <WH3123>, my undefiled <WH8535>; For my head <WH7218> is filled <WH4390> with dew <WH2919>, My locks <WH6977> with the drops <WH7447> of the night <WH3915>.
I have put off <WH6584> my garment <WH3801>; How <WH349> shall I put it on <WH3847>? I have washed <WH7364> my feet <WH7272>; how <WH349> shall I defile them <WH2936>?
My beloved <WH1730> put in <WH7971> his hand <WH3027> by <WH4480> the hole <WH2356> of the door <WH4578>, And my heart was moved for him <WH1993>.

I rose up <WH6965> to open <WH6605> to my beloved <WH1730>; And my hands <WH3027> dropped <WH5197> with myrrh <WH4753>, And my fingers <WH676> with liquid <WH5674> myrrh <WH4753>, Upon the handles <WH3709> of the bolt <WH4514>.

I opened <WH6605> to my beloved <WH1730>; But my beloved <WH1730> had withdrawn <WH2559> himself <WH5674>, and was gone. My soul <WH5315> had failed <WH3318> me when he spake <WH1696>: I sought <WH1245> him <WH4672>, but I could not find him <WH7121>; I called him <WH6030>, but he gave me no answer.

The watchmen <WH8104> that go about <WH5437> the city <WH5892> found <WH4672> me <WH5221>, They smote me <WH6481>, they wounded me <WH8104>; The keepers of the walls <WH2346> took away <WH5375> my mantle from me <WH7289>.
I adjure <WH7650> you <WH1323>, O daughters of Jerusalem <WH3389>, If ye find <WH4672> my beloved <WH1730>, That ye tell <WH5046> him <WH2470>, that I am sick from love <WH160>.

What is thy beloved <WH1730> more than another beloved <WH1730>, O thou fairest <WH3303> among women <WH802>? What is thy beloved <WH1730> more than another beloved <WH1730>, That thou <WH3602> dost so adjure us <WH7650>?
My beloved <WH1730> is white <WH6703> and ruddy <WH122>, The chiefest <WH1713> among ten thousand <WH7233>.
His head <WH7218> is as the most <WH3800> fine gold <WH6337>; His locks <WH6977> are bushy <WH8534>, and black <WH7838> as a raven <WH6158>.
His eyes <WH5869> are like doves <WH3123> beside the water <WH4325> - brooks <WH650>, Washed <WH7364> with milk <WH2461>, and fitly set <WH3427>.
His cheeks <WH3895> are as a bed <WH6170> of spices <WH1314>, As banks of sweet <WH4840> herbs <WH4026>: His lips <WH8193> are as lilies <WH7799>, dropping <WH5197> liquid <WH5674> myrrh <WH4753>.
His hands <WH3027> are as rings <WH1550> of gold <WH2091> set <WH4390> with beryl <WH8658>: His body <WH4578> is as ivory <WH8127> work <WH6247> overlaid <WH5968> with sapphires <WH5601>.

His legs <WH7785> are as pillars <WH5982> of marble <WH8336>, set <WH3245> upon sockets <WH134> of fine gold <WH6337>: His aspect <WH4758> is like Lebanon <WH3844>, excellent <WH977> as the cedars <WH730>.
His mouth <WH2441> is most sweet <WH4477>; Yea <WH4261>, he is altogether lovely. This is my beloved <WH1730>, and this is my friend <WH7453>, O daughters <WH1323> of Jerusalem <WH3389>.
